articles.headline: Trump Admits Downplaying the Virus Knowing It Was ‘Deadly Stuff’
articles.snippet: In taped interviews with the journalist Bob Woodward, the president said as early as February that the virus was more dangerous than the flu, even as he told the country otherwise.
articles.abstract: In taped interviews with the journalist Bob Woodward, the president said as early as February that the virus was more dangerous than the flu, even as he told the country otherwise.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Trump acknowledged to the journalist Bob Woodward that he knowingly played down the coronavirus earlier this year even though he was aware it was life-threatening and vastly more serious than the seasonal flu.

articles.headline: Tiffany’s $16 Billion Sale Falls Apart in Face of Pandemic and Tariffs
articles.snippet: The luxury giant LVMH Moët Hennessy Louis Vuitton backed out of its deal to buy the jeweler.
articles.abstract: The luxury giant LVMH Moët Hennessy Louis Vuitton backed out of its deal to buy the jeweler.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last November, LVMH Moët Hennessy Louis Vuitton, the world’s largest luxury goods conglomerate, announced plans to acquire Tiffany & Company, the American jeweler founded by Charles Lewis Tiffany in 1837 and famed for its robin egg blue boxes and diamond engagement rings.
articles.byline: By Lauren Hirsch and Elizabeth Paton

articles.headline: D.H.S. Downplayed Threats From Russia and White Supremacists, Whistle-Blower Says
articles.snippet: Brian Murphy, the former head of the Department of Homeland Security’s intelligence division, accused senior leaders of warping the agency around President Trump’s political interests.
articles.abstract: Brian Murphy, the former head of the Department of Homeland Security’s intelligence division, accused senior leaders of warping the agency around President Trump’s political interests.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Top officials with the Department of Homeland Security directed agency analysts to downplay threats from violent white supremacy and Russian election interference, a Homeland Security official said in a whistle-blower complaint released on Wednesday.
articles.byline: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Nicholas Fandos

articles.headline: Bankrupt J.C. Penney Is Bought by Mall Operators in Need of Tenants
articles.snippet: The deal for the company’s retail business will keep a number of locations open and is likely to save tens of thousands of jobs.
articles.abstract: The deal for the company’s retail business will keep a number of locations open and is likely to save tens of thousands of jobs.
articles.lead_paragraph: J.C. Penney reached an agreement to sell its retail business to the mall operators Simon Property Group and Brookfield Property Partners on Wednesday, averting a total liquidation that would have had significant ripple effects through the industry and cost tens of thousands of jobs.
articles.byline: By Lauren Hirsch and Sapna Maheshwari

articles.headline: Wildfires Bring New Devastation Across the West
articles.snippet: A record 2.5 million acres have burned in California, while entire communities in Oregon and Washington were largely wiped out.
articles.abstract: A record 2.5 million acres have burned in California, while entire communities in Oregon and Washington were largely wiped out.
articles.lead_paragraph: MALDEN, Wash. — The wildfire arrived with such ferocity that deputies drove through the streets of Malden, Wash., screaming for people to leave. By the time the blaze passed, not even the fire station was spared — the town’s only fire truck was still trapped inside, turned into an ashen hulk.
articles.byline: By Bill Morlin and Mike Baker

articles.headline: Faces of Power: 80% Are White, Even as U.S. Becomes More Diverse
articles.snippet: See the 922 faces of power behind Hollywood, the justice system, big businesses and more; 180 of them identify as Black, Hispanic, Asian, Native American, multiracial or otherwise a person of color.
articles.abstract: See the 922 faces of power behind Hollywood, the justice system, big businesses and more; 180 of them identify as Black, Hispanic, Asian, Native American, multiracial or otherwise a person of color.
articles.lead_paragraph: See the 922 faces of power behind Hollywood, the justice system, big businesses and more; 180 of them identify as Black, Hispanic, Asian, Native American, multiracial or otherwise a person of color.
articles.byline: By Denise Lu, Jon Huang, Ashwin Seshagiri, Haeyoun Park and Troy Griggs

articles.headline: Surging Euro Presents E.C.B. With a Dilemma
articles.snippet: A rising currency is eroding the competitiveness of European exporters. Central bankers are starting to worry.
articles.abstract: A rising currency is eroding the competitiveness of European exporters. Central bankers are starting to worry.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — European policymakers appear to have contained economic destruction from the pandemic by administering a strong dose of monetary policy, government stimulus, and restrictions on travel and gatherings. But the measures came with an unwelcome side effect.

articles.headline: Do Jobless Benefits Deter Workers? Some Employers Say Yes. Studies Don’t.
articles.snippet: A $600-a-week supplement that expired in July has been credited with bolstering the economy. Its impact on hiring is central to a political fight.
articles.abstract: A $600-a-week supplement that expired in July has been credited with bolstering the economy. Its impact on hiring is central to a political fight.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Clips & Clamps, a metal forming company in Plymouth, Mich., advertised for a die setter and operator last year, more than a hundred applications came sailing in.

articles.headline: In Encounters With Black Leaders, Trump Has Chosen Photo Ops Over Substance
articles.snippet: The president claims he is a champion of Black Americans. But those who have tried to work with him tell a different story.
articles.abstract: The president claims he is a champion of Black Americans. But those who have tried to work with him tell a different story.
articles.lead_paragraph: On Martin Luther King’s Birthday in January 2017, Donald J. Trump, then the president-elect, welcomed a group of civil rights leaders, led by Dr. King’s eldest son, into his office in Trump Tower.

articles.headline: London Offices Aren’t Refilling Fast Enough for Shops Relying on Them
articles.snippet: The British government and business lobby want workers to return to support surrounding businesses, but some city offices are only 15 percent full.
articles.abstract: The British government and business lobby want workers to return to support surrounding businesses, but some city offices are only 15 percent full.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Schroders, a big asset management firm, wants more of its workers to return to its office in the City of London. Over the summer, it encouraged people to come in for a day to test their commute and so the firm could demonstrate the new safety measures in place, including an app to order food from the canteen.

articles.headline: Citigroup’s Fraser to Be First Woman to Lead a Big Wall Street Bank
articles.snippet: Jane Fraser, Citigroup’s president, will replace Michael Corbat as chief executive in February as he retires after eight years.
articles.abstract: Jane Fraser, Citigroup’s president, will replace Michael Corbat as chief executive in February as he retires after eight years.
articles.lead_paragraph: Booms and busts and scams and panics have changed Wall Street in many ways over the decades, but one thing has stubbornly remained the same: The top jobs have always gone to men. Now, that last citadel is about to fall.
articles.byline: By Emily Flitter and Anupreeta Das

articles.headline: Cleaners Demand Harassment Safeguards From the Booking Service Handy
articles.snippet: Workers for a home services company say they face sexual harassment and unfair fees. A civil rights group is asking California regulators to step in.
articles.abstract: Workers for a home services company say they face sexual harassment and unfair fees. A civil rights group is asking California regulators to step in.
articles.lead_paragraph: BERKELEY, Calif. — It was supposed to be just another routine job for Patti Cris, who in early 2018 was a contract worker for the home services booking site Handy. She got the key for the San Jose apartment she was scheduled to clean while its occupant was gone, and remembers knocking twice and announcing herself, just to make sure.
articles.byline: By Kellen Browning and Kate Conger
